metadata.title: 7 Rs of Cloud Migration Strategy Catalog
metadata.source: AWS Migration Framework + DoD Modernization Guide
metadata.description: Comprehensive catalog of the 7 Rs cloud migration strategies tailored for DoD/GovCloud environments with ATO impact assessments and scoring criteria.

strategies.name: Rehost
strategies.description: Lift-and-shift migration of applications to AWS GovCloud with no code changes. Workloads are moved as-is onto cloud infrastructure, preserving existing architecture and configurations. Best suited for rapid datacenter exits and baseline cloud adoption.
when_to_use: Datacenter exit timelines are aggressive and non-negotiable
Application has no planned feature enhancements in near term
Existing ATO artifacts are current and transfer-ready
Application architecture is already well-documented
Cost savings from infrastructure consolidation are the primary driver
when_not_to_use: Application has significant technical debt requiring remediation
Current architecture cannot meet cloud scalability requirements
Licensing model does not support cloud deployment
Application depends on hardware-specific interfaces or custom drivers

infrastructure_compatibility.description: Degree to which current infrastructure maps to GovCloud compute, storage, and networking services

dependency_portability.description: Ease of migrating dependent services, databases, and middleware without modification

licensing_transferability.description: Whether existing software licenses permit cloud deployment or require BYOL arrangements

data_migration_complexity.description: Volume and sensitivity of data requiring transfer, including CUI handling requirements

operational_readiness.description: Team familiarity with cloud operations and availability of runbooks for cloud-based management

strategies.name: Replatform
strategies.description: Lift-tinker-and-shift migration that introduces targeted optimizations during the move to GovCloud. Involves minor modifications such as swapping to managed services (e.g., RDS instead of self-managed databases) without altering core application architecture.
when_to_use: Managed services can replace self-hosted middleware with minimal code changes
Database migration to RDS or Aurora provides clear operational benefits
Application can benefit from auto-scaling with minor configuration updates
Team wants incremental cloud-native improvements without full refactor
Operational overhead of current platform is a significant cost driver
when_not_to_use: Application requires fundamental architectural changes to function in cloud
Managed service equivalents do not exist in GovCloud region
Data residency or sovereignty requirements prevent use of managed services
Cost of managed services exceeds self-hosted operational costs at current scale

managed_service_availability.description: Availability of equivalent managed services in AWS GovCloud for current self-hosted components

modification_scope.description: Extent of configuration and code changes needed to adopt managed services

operational_improvement.description: Reduction in operational burden, patching requirements, and maintenance overhead

cost_optimization.description: Net cost impact of moving to managed services versus current hosting model

security_posture_change.description: Impact on security controls and shared responsibility model changes with managed services

strategies.name: Refactor
strategies.description: Modify existing application code to better leverage cloud-native features while preserving the overall architecture. Involves updating code patterns, adopting cloud SDKs, improving configuration management, and optimizing for cloud services without a full architectural redesign.
when_to_use: Application needs performance improvements achievable through cloud-native patterns
Codebase requires modernization of specific modules but not full rearchitecture
Team wants to adopt cloud-native services like S3, SQS, or SNS incrementally
Technical debt in specific components blocks operational efficiency
Compliance requirements demand updated security patterns in code
when_not_to_use: Application architecture itself is fundamentally incompatible with cloud
Refactoring scope creep risk is high due to tightly coupled modules
Vendor will not support modified versions of their application
Time constraints do not allow for development and testing cycles
A COTS replacement exists that better meets mission requirements

code_modularity.description: Degree of separation between application modules enabling targeted refactoring

cloud_service_adoption.description: Potential to replace custom code with GovCloud-native services and SDKs

test_coverage.description: Existing automated test coverage enabling safe refactoring with regression detection

team_capability.description: Development team expertise with target cloud services and modern patterns

technical_debt_reduction.description: Measurable improvement in maintainability, readability, and defect density

compliance_alignment.description: Alignment of refactored code with NIST 800-53 security control requirements

strategies.name: Rearchitect
strategies.description: Fundamentally redesign and rebuild the application using cloud-native architecture. Typically involves decomposing monoliths into microservices, adopting serverless patterns, implementing event-driven designs, and building for horizontal scalability. Requires full ATO reassessment.
when_to_use: Current architecture cannot scale to meet projected mission requirements
Monolithic design prevents independent deployment and team autonomy
Application must support multi-region or multi-classification deployment
Legacy technology stack has reached end-of-life with no vendor support
Mission-critical system requires high availability and fault tolerance beyond current capabilities
when_not_to_use: Application is nearing planned retirement within 24 months
Budget and timeline constraints cannot accommodate full rebuild
Existing architecture adequately meets current and projected requirements
Team lacks cloud-native development expertise and training timeline is insufficient
Regulatory requirements mandate specific architectural patterns incompatible with cloud-native

architectural_gap.description: Severity of mismatch between current architecture and target cloud-native requirements

mission_criticality.description: Importance of the application to mission operations and impact of downtime

scalability_requirements.description: Need for elastic scaling, multi-region deployment, or high-availability patterns

team_readiness.description: Team expertise in microservices, containers, serverless, and cloud-native DevSecOps

ato_reassessment_capacity.description: Organization capacity to execute full ATO reassessment including new boundary definitions

long_term_roi.description: Projected return on investment over 5-year horizon including operational savings

strategies.name: Repurchase
strategies.description: Replace the existing application with a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) or government off-the-shelf (GOTS) product, typically a SaaS solution authorized for GovCloud. Requires full ATO boundary redefinition and new authorization package since the underlying system changes entirely.
when_to_use: A FedRAMP-authorized or DoD IL4+ SaaS solution exists that meets mission needs
Cost of maintaining custom-built application exceeds commercial alternative
Custom application duplicates functionality available in mature commercial products
Vendor ecosystem provides better integration and long-term support
Organization wants to shift from custom development to configuration-based delivery
when_not_to_use: No FedRAMP High or IL4+ authorized product meets mission-specific requirements
Vendor lock-in risk is unacceptable for mission-critical operations
Data migration from legacy to SaaS is technically infeasible or cost-prohibitive
Unique DoD workflows require extensive customization that negates SaaS benefits
Current application provides competitive or mission advantage not replicable by COTS

product_fit.description: Functional coverage of mission requirements by the replacement product without customization

fedramp_authorization.description: FedRAMP High or DoD IL4+ authorization status and reciprocity eligibility

data_migration_feasibility.description: Complexity of migrating existing data, including CUI, to the replacement product

total_cost_of_ownership.description: 5-year TCO comparison between replacement product licensing and current system maintenance

vendor_viability.description: Vendor financial stability, GovCloud commitment, and DoD contract vehicle availability

strategies.name: Retire
strategies.description: Decommission the application entirely. Data is archived per DoD retention policies, dependent systems are migrated to alternative solutions, and the ATO authorization is formally closed. Reduces attack surface, operational costs, and compliance burden.
when_to_use: Application functionality has been superseded by another authorized system
User base has declined below operational cost justification threshold
Mission requirement the application served no longer exists
Application poses unacceptable security risk that cannot be cost-effectively remediated
Datacenter exit requires disposition of all workloads including decommission candidates
when_not_to_use: Any active users or downstream systems still depend on the application
Data retention requirements have not been fully assessed and addressed
No alternative system exists for remaining mission functions
Contractual obligations require continued operation for a defined period

dependency_analysis.description: Completeness of upstream and downstream dependency mapping and migration planning

data_disposition.description: Compliance of data archival plan with DoD 5015.02 records management and CUI handling

cost_savings.description: Projected annual savings from decommissioning including infrastructure, licensing, and personnel

risk_reduction.description: Reduction in organizational attack surface and compliance burden from system removal

stakeholder_alignment.description: Confirmation from all stakeholders that retirement is acceptable and alternatives are in place

strategies.name: Retain
strategies.description: Keep the application in its current environment with no migration. The system remains on-premises or in its existing hosting arrangement. Applicable when migration is not justified, technically feasible, or when regulatory constraints prohibit cloud deployment. Reassess periodically.
when_to_use: Application has hard regulatory or classification constraints preventing cloud hosting
Migration cost exceeds projected benefits within the planning horizon
Application is scheduled for retirement within 12 months
Technical dependencies on specialized hardware cannot be replicated in cloud
Application is in active development with a future cloud-native redesign planned
when_not_to_use: Datacenter exit mandate requires all workloads to migrate or decommission
Current hosting environment is reaching end-of-life with no renewal option
Security posture of current environment fails to meet minimum DoD requirements
Operational costs of current environment significantly exceed cloud equivalent

migration_blocker_validity.description: Legitimacy and documentation of technical, regulatory, or contractual migration blockers

current_environment_viability.description: Remaining operational life and supportability of current hosting infrastructure

cost_justification.description: Financial analysis showing retention is more cost-effective than migration alternatives

reassessment_plan.description: Defined timeline and criteria for re-evaluating migration readiness

risk_acceptance.description: Formal AO risk acceptance documentation for continued operation in current environment
